Definitions.Definition_Content: Let $R$ be a ring. A subset $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ is called an ideal in $R$ if: (i) $\mathfrak{a}$ is an additive subgroup of $R$. (ii) For any $r \in R$ and $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, it holds that $ra \in \mathfrak{a}$.
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.

Definitions.Concept_Name: System of Generators of an Ideal
Definitions.Definition_Content: Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Let $R$ be an integral domain. Then two principal ideals $\mathfrak{a}=(a)$ and $\mathfrak{b}=(b)$ of $R$ coincide if and only if there is a unit $c \in R^{*}$ such that $b=c a$. Proof: If $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{b}$, there is no loss of generality in assuming $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{b} \neq 0$. Then $b \in \mathfrak{a}$ and there exists an element $c \in R$ such that $b=c a$. Likewise, we have $a \in \mathfrak{b}$ and therefore an element $c^{\prime} \in R$ such that $a=c^{\prime} b$. Then $b=c a=c c^{\prime} b$, and thus $\left(1-c c^{\prime}\right) b=0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain and $b$ is nonzero due to $\mathfrak{b} \neq 0$, we get $c c^{\prime}=1$, and $c$ is a unit. The reverse implication is trivial.
